comments.commentBody: Thanks, Jane. I also grew up playing the original Monopoly, though more games were started than finished.
I love all the place names one finds on Monopoly from other countries. The game itself could be called monotony.

Tom G., your blog, with the comments about Momopoly was most informative. I grew up with the traditional game as did my girls.  Real ones, DL.  I just went back to Monday's blog (I'd not caught up with it before) and was very moved by your recount of your friend's memorial.  Very special for you to share your feelings with us.

Don't forget that the developed countries who send their children to preschool, encourage play and social development and NOT academics for 4 year olds. The United States continues to perpetuate the myth that early academics lead to later academic success. I lived abroad with a 4 year old, who began preschool in the Netherlands. To achieve the quality of what he received there, I would need to pay at least $700 per month in the United States. In the Netherlands, he had a highly qualified, wonderful teacher who offered amazing parent education evenings on top of a warm environment for her students.. The parents and children loved her. For my 4 year old, I could choose a school from many educational philosophies (Waldorf, Dalton, Montessori, Jena Plan, Catholic, etc, etc) that would be considered only in private schools in the United States.

In Finland, children do not begin school until age 7, and it is not considered advantageous for young children to read since everyone knows that kids need to play.....Of course the Finnish state pays for high quality, play based childcare for children under the age of 7!

The late NYS assemblywoman Constance Cook often remarked that the women's liberation movement would reach its ultimate goal when men no longer had to wear ties. In other words, liberating women would also liberate men. And I think she'd be impressed with the current state of affairs, in which many men feel comfortable being stay-at-home dads and some are even okay with earning lower wages. This was the movement's vision.

But--and here's my point--in order to achieve real equality, both sides need to engage. We've come this far with the vision outlined by women, but they can't, and shouldn't, call all the shots. The next steps require male input. So Snoop--what is your vision for male social roles?

Of course there are "male roles". It's that they are rather similar to female roles - love, parenthood (if chosen), mutual providence, etc. etc. Men actually have more choices than before.

Your basic problem, is that you expect an *exclusive* role for men..

I'm always skeptical when research finds that only men are unable to adjust to new gender roles: "On the one hand, men should like the prospect of sharing income with a high-earning woman. On the other hand, they may find it difficult to adjust to a new social role."
Or this: "wives often try to enact traditional gender roles in an apparent effort to reassure their husbands that they are not a threat."

Huh. So when it comes to gender and the sexual marketplace, men are irrational but women are not. I don't buy that. From my experience, women still value men as partners primarily based upon their potential economic contribution to any future household. Men with higher incomes are more desirable. Therefore, men try to maximize their sexual desirability by maximizing their income. When men meet women with equivalent or higher incomes, men are concerned that women might be less interested in them.

This is not men not adjusting to a new social role-- this is men reacting to the fact that men DO NOT HAVE a new social role. While the feminist movement has given women many more choices in self-definition over the past 50 years, men have been stuck in the same box. Change male social roles and you might find that men are not "threatened" by higher female income, and do in fact welcome it. As women tend to write articles on gender and conduct gender research, this point is often missed-- "gender" discussions are typically lack a male perspective.

If these surveillance programs help to prevent terrorist attacks , then it is good. No question about it. However the question is about those who abuse the system for personal/political/religious/social agendas. When corrupt people can access to your personal data, they get to know your likes, dislikes, fears, strengths, weaknesses, desires etc. They can use those personal info to change our through process or our behavior or even ruin our life.
see my story on word press or You Tube.
Search for Stalking Nightmare

I"ve polled lots of early educators and read tons of research about math anxiety, and nobody ever talks about preschoolers fearing math. People are not born with math anxiety. All little kids love to count, pour sand from one volume to another to see what will fit, measure objects, ask questions, test conjectures, and seek patterns.

Math anxiety onset is an evenly distributed graph from primary school through college (McAnallen, 2012). Most kids enter K loving math. Most kids finish schooling hating it. We lose them all along the way.

Perhaps it's not the two different groups of kids that's our problem. Perhaps it's the overly rigid, authoritarian, top-down, prescriptive, dry, irrelevant, impoverished version of math they get in school. You know, the kind argued for by the authors of this ridiculous essay, which you seem to support.

Because you gave your credentials, I'll give mine. [science/math background/a few grad degrees including one earned during a Rhodes scholarship/proud elementary school teacher/math coach/writing a professional development book about math teaching for elementary school colleagues with math anxiety...]

It was down here too. And internet was SHUT OFF downtown where the protests were going on. If you're watching the news, you might wonder why there are NO images of Mineirão last night, that's where everything went down. People were beat up and there was NO vandalism, police was completely abusive and they simply hunt people down inside UFMG, where they're not even supposed to be allowed in. This is not a democracy, it's a dictatorship, and the worst thing is, people don't even know it.

Vanine, thank you for posting these.

I am an American living in Brazil, where I have had a permanent residency visa for over 20 years. I lived here in the late 80s and early 90s and returned two years ago. I love this country. If you will forgive what might seem like self promotion, yesterday I published both on FaceBook and in my personal blog my take on what is happening here, "Brazil - It's Not about 20 Cents.". For those Americans who are interested, please take a look. It hopefully will help put some things in perspective for you.

http://www.wjshelton.blogspot.com.br/

https://www.facebook.com/RandomNotesfromSouthoftheEquator?fref=ts

Please forgive the typos in the blog.

See you in the streets!

Here's what is happening in Brasil:

https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=615139981843980&set=a.302397...

https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?v=780469541982625

I guess there are many people in these protests who aren't actually AGAINST the Confederations Cup and the World Cup, they're just against all the unfair situations that happens every single day in the country. Brazil have the living cost from Switzerland, while the life quality is comparable to Mexico or Russia... The prices "paid" to make both competitions, plus the increases in the bus fare in the biggest city in the country, São Paulo (11 million inhabitants), were the "last straw" in one already overflowed cup. For example, the "Mané Garrincha Stadium", in Brasília, capital of the country, cost R$1.5 billion, what means in something about $700 million. That's too much for a stadium. Is impossible that one single stadium cost that much, and this just reinforces the idea created about the Brazilian politician, a bunch of old corrupted foxes. An World Cup should generate ONLY benefits for the country, it should develop the country, what apparently happened in South Africa. The same isn't happening in Brazil, unfortunately.
By the way, the situation is really unbearable, as you said... I hope I have explained it the best way possible (in my viewpoint, of course), although english is not my native language...

Sorry Carlos, but you're wrong. Brazil does not need a fourth power. PEC37 is ultimately necessary to adjust powers of investigatora. What Brazil needs is a reform of its laws and judiciary to enable emprisonment of criminals (corrupt people, murderers, criminal teenagers, etc.).

American people, help us spread:
A certain minister here in Brazil want to approve the PEC-37 on 26/06, this law either REMOVE the power of public ministry to investigate politicians, ie, let corruption and embezzlement (which are absurd in Brazil ) can be made. We are tired of this nonsense, this system, we do not want and canopies are NOT the country of football, we want a just and peaceful world. Please help us. thank you

We are tired of this nonsense, this system, we do not want and canopies are NOT the country of football, we want a just and peaceful world. Please help us. thank you

Also, I find it funny - or it would be funny, if it weren't tragic - that quotes from Orwell's 1984 keep coming to mind. War is Peace. Freedom is Slavery. Ignorance is Strength.
If you THINK you know what's going on in Brazil, you have NO idea. It's much worse. I've seen things I NEVER thought I'd see assuming I live in a democratic country.
"Until they became conscious they will never rebel, and until after they have rebelled they cannot become conscious."

This is not true at all! She is truly incompetent, and her economic team is a nightmare. They had been so reckless that now inflation is back!
They´re ruining the country!

Dilma is a populist, she is negotiating every political move with taxpayer money, without ant moral consideration. She sells the country every day and anyone praising her seems to be benefiting from such schemes. Dilma asks Lula even before she goes to the toilet. Wake up, Brazil!

President Dilma Rousseff has been highly regarded by the Brazilian people as a competent, stern and fiscally responsible leader. It is not accurate to try to label her government as a corrupt coalition as some opposition groups have attempted to do. Hers is a popular government, not populist as some segments of the Brazilian society try to convince the world! Although the Brazilian economy has presented some problems lately, in great part due to the economic crisis that has affected the Western world in recent years, Dilma Rousseff's government has promoted social inclusion, civil rights and economic development. I am proud and grateful for Dilma Rousseff's leadership!!!!

Dilma is a populist, she is negotiating every political move with taxpayer money, without ant moral consideration. She sells the country every day and anyone praising her seems to be benefiting from such schemes. Dilma asks Lula even before she goes to the toilet. Wake up, Brazil!

Which São Paulo do you live in?
I'd love to move in! To say Dilma is regarded by the Brazilian as a competent leader is just delusional. Her approval ratings are falling like a waterfall, and is totally populist, she pays out people votes by handing "Bolsas" around the country.

When Lula was in the power, things didn't go downfall like it's going because he is an awesome spokeman. He really made up a lot of things and people had orgasms when he yelled @ mic and brought Corinthians analogies and other popular stuff to the stand.

Truth be told, Dilma is inherited all Lula's unfinished businesses like the Petrobras poor management scandal but Dilma's last resort was ridiculous. She looked for shelter by secretly meeting Lula in a hotel. Does she realize she is the current president and Lula oficially represents nothing to the country right now?

The saddest thing is: I voted on her.

The Workers Party (PT) government has proven itself as the most corrupt Brazil has had in the last 50 years. PT apparatchik and politically reliable cronies have been placed all over government bureaus and government owned companies (such as PETROBRAS), replacing career personnel.  Besides rampant corruption with slap wrist punishments, if any, PT has proved itself to be thoroughly incompetent in managing the country. Brazil's growth during the last ten years was due to the sound economical and managerial principles established by presidents Franco and Cardoso, between 1992 and 2002. The Workers Party systematically voted against all the reforming legislation, which created the basis for Brazil's growth. Lula and Dilma Roussef just took advantage of the vast institutional reform and rode out the world's generalized growth wave while uttering socialist slogans and courting third world dictators. Regretfully,  Dilma Roussef will probably be reelected and Lula will still be pulling strings behind the scenes. Communism, which is extinct all over the world (North Korea and Cuba are located somewhere out of this planet) still has many sympathizers among Brazilians misguided, and this has to be taken into consideration when analyzing Brazilian politics. I see a bleak future for Brazil if we do not oust the Workers Party from power, and start applying sound principles to the economy, but I still hope for the best.

President Dilma Rousseff has been highly regarded by the Brazilian people as a competent, stern and fiscally responsible leader. It is not accurate to try to label her government as a corrupt coalition as some opposition groups have attempted to do. Hers is a popular government, not populist as some segments of the Brazilian society try to convince the world! Although the Brazilian economy has presented some problems lately, in great part due to the economic crisis that has affected the Western world in recent years, Dilma Rousseff's government has promoted social inclusion, civil rights and economic development. I am proud and grateful for Dilma Rousseff's leadership!!!!
